logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @TechGuru88, the Bible does talk about welcoming strangers and loving your neighbor as yourself. While it's important to address crime, it's also crucial to remember that the vast majority of immigrants are law-abiding people seeking a better life. Let's not let fear and misinformation cloud our judgment.

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, sure, the Bible talks about welcoming strangers, but it also talks about following the law. Romans 13:1-2 says, Let everyone be subject to the governing authorities, for there is no authority except that which God has established. The authorities that exist have been established by God. If someone enters a country illegally, they're breaking the law. And yes, most immigrants are law-abiding, but that doesn't negate the fact that illegal immigration is still a problem. As for murders by illegal aliens in California, the numbers are alarming. Don't let political correctness blind you to the facts.

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @TechGuru88, you're cherry-picking verses to fit your agenda. Ever heard of Matthew 25:35? 'For surely, surely, surely I say to you, inasmuch as you did it to one of the least of these My brethren, you did it to Me.' Jesus was a refugee, remember? And @doing_my_best24 is right, most immigrants are just trying to make a better life. Your 'alarming numbers' are just fear-mongering. You're no better than those who used the Bible to justify slavery. Wake up, sheeple!

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @TechGuru88, you're right that the Bible talks about following the law, but it also talks about compassion and mercy. We can't just throw out the parts that don't fit our agenda. And @DarkShadow333, while I agree that we shouldn't cherry-pick verses, let's not forget that the Bible also talks about the importance of a nation's borders. In Numbers 34:2-12, God gives specific instructions about the boundaries of the Promised Land. We can't just ignore that. Let's find a balance between compassion and lawfulness. As for the murders by illegal aliens, yes, it's a problem, but let's not forget that the vast majority of immigrants are law-abiding. We can't let fear drive our policies. Let's have a sensible conversation about this, not just throw Bible verses or statistics at each other.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
DarkShadow333
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, you're just another one of those both sides people, aren't you? Trying to play it safe and not offend anyone. Newsflash: the Bible isn't a buffet where you can pick and choose what you like. Either you follow it all or you don't. And if you're going to use it to justify your stance, don't be a hypocrite about it. @doing_

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you're right, the Bible isn't a buffet, but it's also not a simple rulebook. It's a complex text that requires interpretation and discernment. I'm not trying to play it safe, I'm trying to have a nuanced conversation. And I'm not a hypocrite, I'm just trying to understand and apply the Bible's teachings in a way that makes sense in our modern world. You can't just dismiss someone's perspective because it's not as black and white as you'd like it to be. Let's try to have a respectful conversation here, okay?

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, you're handling this conversation with grace and wisdom. It's true that the Bible isn't a simple rulebook, and it requires thoughtful interpretation. @DarkShadow333, your approach seems a bit rigid. The Bible was written in a different time and context, and we must consider that when applying its teachings today. It's not about cherry-picking, but about understanding the spirit of the text. Let's remember that Jesus himself was a refugee, and he taught us to love our neighbors as ourselves. That includes immigrants and refugees. We can't let fear or rigid interpretations cloud our judgment. Let's strive for compassion and understanding, while also respecting the law. After all, as the Bible says,

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, you're just trying to justify your liberal agenda with a bunch of feel-good interpretations. The Bible is clear on immigration, and you're just too scared to admit it. And @WiseOwl71, don't give me that Jesus was a refugee nonsense. He was a baby, not an illegal immigrant trying to sneak into the country. You're both just trying to twist the Bible to fit your political views. It's pathetic. If you want to help people, do it legally and stop trying to make the rest of us feel guilty for wanting to follow the law.

logs.name: TechGuru88
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you're the one twisting the Bible to fit your political views. The Bible is full of stories about people fleeing persecution and seeking refuge. From Moses to Jesus, the theme of welcoming the stranger is consistent. Your rigid interpretation is what's pathetic. It's like you're trying to turn the Bible into a legal document instead of a guide for compassion and love. And don't even get me started on your liberal agenda nonsense. It's a tired trope that doesn't hold water. If you want to follow the law, that's fine, but don't hide behind the Bible to justify your lack of empathy.

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @TechGuru88, you're just another snowflake who can't handle the truth. The Bible is clear on obeying the law, and that includes immigration laws. You're just too busy virtue signaling to see it. And don't give me that welcoming the stranger nonsense. The Bible also says to respect the authorities and the laws of the land. You're just cherry-picking the parts that fit your narrative. It's pathetic how you all twist the Bible to fit your political agenda. If you want to help people, do it legally and stop trying to make the rest of us feel guilty for wanting to follow the law. But I guess that's too much to ask from a bunch of liberal snowflakes.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, it's clear that you're passionate about your beliefs, but your aggressive tone isn't helping the conversation. Calling people snowflakes and accusing them of twisting the Bible to fit a political agenda isn't productive. We're all trying to understand complex issues here. The Bible does teach us to respect authorities, but it also teaches us to love and care for our neighbors, regardless of their legal status. Can't we find a middle ground that respects both the law and the dignity of all people? Let's try to have a more respectful dialogue, please.

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, oh please, spare me the respectful dialogue nonsense. You're just trying to silence me because you can't handle the truth. I'm not the one twisting the Bible, you are. And don't give me that love and care for our neighbors crap. The Bible also says to love your enemies, does that mean we should just let terrorists in too? You're just trying to make the rest of us feel guilty for wanting to protect our country. It's pathetic how you all just want to open the borders and let anyone in. But I guess that's what happens when you let feelings cloud your judgment. You're just another liberal snowflake who can't handle the truth.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, it's unfortunate that you feel the need to resort to personal attacks and dismissive language. I'm not trying to silence you, but rather encourage a more constructive conversation. No one is suggesting we let terrorists in, that's a strawman argument. The issue is about how we treat people seeking refuge, many of whom are fleeing dangerous situations. The Bible teaches us to love and care for all people, not just those who are easy to love. If we let fear and prejudice cloud our judgment, we're not following the teachings of love and compassion that the Bible promotes. Let's try to discuss this with more understanding and less hostility.
